content.title: Substrate Selection for Uromastyx
content.content: Uromastyx come from arid, sandy regions where they dig and shelter in burrows. A deep, packable sand or sandy soil is the best match and supports natural behavior.
In the wild, these lizards live on sandy or sandy-soil terrain with firm, compacted layers that allow shallow burrows. Captive substrate should be fine, stable, and deep enough to hold shape.
Key requirement: Provide at least 4 inches of packed substrate with a dry surface and slightly denser lower layers for burrowing.
Fine sand or sandy soil blends work best. Avoid sharp or oversized particles.

content.text: Substrate Comparison:

content.content: A simple DIY blend provides excellent structure and saves money.

content.text: DIY Substrate Mix:

content.content: Mixing Instructions: Combine dry ingredients thoroughly, add small amounts of water until the mix holds shape when squeezed, then pack it firmly in the enclosure. Let it dry before adding the lizard.
Impaction is far more likely when heat, UVB, or hydration are inadequate. Correct husbandry reduces risk significantly.

content.text: Risk Factors:

rows: Use high-output UVB and correct distance
Provide fresh water and hydrating greens
Use fine sand or sandy soil

content.content: Healthy heat and UVB are the primary safeguards. Substrate is rarely the sole cause of impaction when husbandry is correct.
Temporary non-loose substrates are recommended for illness, injury, or quarantine.

content.text: Temporary Alternatives:

content.content: Recovery Protocol: Reintroduce loose substrate once the animal is stable, temperatures are verified, and eating is consistent.
Arid bioactive setups can work, but the surface should remain mostly dry. Use hardy, drought-tolerant plants and a cleanup crew suited to warm, low-humidity conditions.

content.text: Bioactive Layer Structure:

content.content: Keep the surface dry and only lightly moisten lower layers so burrows hold shape without raising ambient humidity.

content.text: Maintenance Schedule:

rows: Replace all substrate and disinfect enclosure

content.text: Unsafe Options:

rows: Can be ingested in large amounts

content.content: Avoid coarse or sharp substrates. Uromastyx thrive on fine sand or sandy soil with stable structure.
